poem:
Young Futures

Knives carve futures into stone,
whispered threats on screens alone.
Wolves in Wolverhampton howl,
Croydon's cries, Nottingham's scowl.
Pressures twist their fragile days,
minds caught in a binary haze.
Through pixel and blade, they roam,
seeking softer skies, a gentler home.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Yvette Cooper says today’s teenagers have it ‘much, much harder’ Teenagers have it “much, much harder” than previous generations because of knives, mental health pressures and social media, Yvette Cooper has said, as she announced plans for a new unit to prevent violent crime among young people.After the deaths of young people in stabbings in Nottingham, Wolverhampton and Croydon, Cooper told the Guardian she was initiating a new cross-government “young futures” unit to be based". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
